title: 1 Samuel Chapter 26 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 26 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 26 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 26.

questions.question: Who came to Saul to inform him about David hiding in the hill of Hachilah?
questions.correctAnswer: The Ziphites
questions.explanation: The Ziphites came to Saul with information about David, as stated in 1 Samuel 26:1.

questions.question: How many chosen men did Saul take with him to seek David in the wilderness of Ziph?
questions.correctAnswer: Three thousand
questions.explanation: Saul went with three thousand chosen men to seek David, as mentioned in 1 Samuel 26:2.

questions.question: Where did Saul pitch his camp when he went after David?
questions.correctAnswer: In the hill of Hachilah
questions.explanation: Saul pitched in the hill of Hachilah before Jeshimon, as described in 1 Samuel 26:3.

questions.question: Who did David ask to go down with him to Saul's camp?
questions.correctAnswer: Abishai
questions.explanation: David asked Abishai to go down with him to Saul's camp, as seen in 1 Samuel 26:6.

questions.question: What was stuck in the ground at Saul's bolster while he was sleeping?
questions.correctAnswer: His spear
questions.explanation: Saul's spear was stuck in the ground at his bolster when he was sleeping, according to 1 Samuel 26:7.

questions.question: What did Abishai want to do to Saul when he found him sleeping?
questions.correctAnswer: Smite him with the spear
questions.explanation: Abishai wanted to smite Saul with the spear, but David stopped him, as described in 1 Samuel 26:8.

questions.question: Why did David refuse to kill Saul?
options: Because Saul was the Lord's anointed
questions.correctAnswer: Because Saul was the Lord's anointed
questions.explanation: David refused to harm Saul because he was the Lord's anointed, as stated in 1 Samuel 26:9.

questions.question: What two items did David take from Saul's camp?
options: The spear and the cruse of water
questions.correctAnswer: The spear and the cruse of water
questions.explanation: David took the spear and the cruse of water from Saul's bolster, as recorded in 1 Samuel 26:11-12.

questions.question: Where did David stand after leaving Saul's camp?
options: On the top of a hill afar off
At the entrance of the camp
questions.correctAnswer: On the top of a hill afar off
questions.explanation: David stood on the top of a hill far off after getting away from Saul’s camp as mentioned in 1 Samuel 26:13.

questions.question: Who did David call out to after he left Saul's camp?
questions.correctAnswer: Abner
questions.explanation: David called out to Abner, the captain of Saul's host, as stated in 1 Samuel 26:14.

questions.question: True or False: David killed Saul when he had the chance.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David refused to kill Saul because he was the Lord's anointed, as explained in 1 Samuel 26:9-10.

questions.question: True or False: Saul recognized David's voice when David spoke to him from the hill.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Saul recognized David’s voice and called him his son, as noted in 1 Samuel 26:17.

questions.question: True or False: Saul promised not to harm David again after this incident.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Saul promised not to harm David and admitted he had sinned, as recorded in 1 Samuel 26:21.

questions.question: Complete this verse from 1 Samuel 26:20: 'Now therefore, let not my blood fall to the earth before the face of the LORD: for the king of Israel is come out to seek a ______, as when one doth hunt a partridge in the mountains.'
questions.correctAnswer: flea
questions.explanation: David compares Saul's pursuit of him to hunting a flea, as stated in 1 Samuel 26:20.

questions.question: What did David say should be rendered to every man according to 1 Samuel 26:23?
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness and faithfulness
questions.explanation: David wished that the LORD would render righteousness and faithfulness to every man, as stated in 1 Samuel 26:23.

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 26 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 26 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with the temptation to take revenge on someone who wronged them. Based on 1 Samuel 26, what biblical truth would you share?
options: We should not harm the Lord's anointed, trusting God to deliver justice
We should retaliate quickly to prevent further harm
We must always avoid confrontation at all costs
It is better to ignore injustice and remain silent
questions.correctAnswer: We should not harm the Lord's anointed, trusting God to deliver justice
questions.explanation: David refused to kill Saul, the Lord's anointed, saying he would not stretch out his hand against him (1 Samuel 26:9-11, 23). This teaches us to trust God's timing and justice rather than taking revenge ourselves.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 26 teach us about humility when facing opposition?
options: By showing respect even to those who pursue us, like David did with Saul
By asserting our rights forcefully against our enemies
By avoiding all conflicts and running away
By seeking public recognition for our good deeds
questions.correctAnswer: By showing respect even to those who pursue us, like David did with Saul
questions.explanation: David spoke respectfully to Saul and called him 'my lord, O king' despite being pursued by him (1 Samuel 26:17-18, 25). This shows humility and respect toward authority even during trials.

questions.question: A believer is feeling discouraged because they are being unfairly treated. Based on David’s experience in 1 Samuel 26, what encouragement can you offer?
options: Trust that the Lord will deliver you in His time, as He did for David
Fight back immediately to prove your innocence
Ignore the situation and avoid all relationships
Seek revenge to teach others a lesson
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that the Lord will deliver you in His time, as He did for David
questions.explanation: David trusted that the Lord would smite Saul or that his time to die would come (1 Samuel 26:10, 23-24). This encourages believers to patiently trust God's deliverance.

questions.question: What does David’s refusal to kill Saul in 1 Samuel 26 teach us about obedience to God's Word?
options: Obedience means respecting God's anointed and leaving judgment to Him
Obedience requires us to defend ourselves aggressively
Obedience means avoiding all difficult situations
Obedience is about winning at any cost
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience means respecting God's anointed and leaving judgment to Him
questions.explanation: David said no man can stretch forth his hand against the Lord’s anointed and be guiltless (1 Samuel 26:9) and chose not to harm Saul, demonstrating obedience to God's authority.

questions.question: When faced with trials or persecution, how does 1 Samuel 26 guide a believer’s attitude toward God?
options: Maintain faith that God values your life and will deliver you
Become angry and question God’s fairness
Give up on trusting God and rely on yourself
Hide from everyone and avoid prayer
questions.correctAnswer: Maintain faith that God values your life and will deliver you
questions.explanation: David prayed that just as Saul’s life was precious in his eyes, so may his life be precious in the eyes of the Lord who would deliver him (1 Samuel 26:24). This encourages perseverance and trust in God's care.

questions.question: Based on 1 Samuel 26, what example does David set regarding forgiveness and reconciliation?
options: He forgave Saul and wished him well despite Saul’s pursuit
He demanded punishment for Saul’s actions
He avoided Saul completely without speaking
He sought to overthrow Saul immediately
questions.correctAnswer: He forgave Saul and wished him well despite Saul’s pursuit
questions.explanation: David blessed Saul and said he would do great things and prevail (1 Samuel 26:25), showing forgiveness and hope for reconciliation.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 26 encourage integrity in leadership and service to others?
options: By showing David’s respect for Saul as the Lord’s anointed and choosing not to harm him
By encouraging leaders to use force to maintain control
By promoting personal ambition above God’s will
By advising leaders to avoid responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: By showing David’s respect for Saul as the Lord’s anointed and choosing not to harm him
questions.explanation: David honored Saul’s position as king and refrained from violence, demonstrating integrity and respect in leadership (1 Samuel 26:9-11, 23).

questions.question: True or False: David took Saul’s spear and cruse of water while Saul was sleeping, then openly attacked him in his camp.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David took the spear and cruse quietly and did not harm Saul, nor did he attack openly (1 Samuel 26:11-12).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Samuel 26, David believed it was right to kill Saul because Saul was pursuing him.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David refused to kill Saul because he recognized Saul as the Lord’s anointed and trusted God for justice (1 Samuel 26:9-10).

questions.question: When David confronted Abner from a distance, what biblical virtue was he demonstrating?
options: Boldness in addressing wrongdoing with respect
Avoidance of conflict at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: Boldness in addressing wrongdoing with respect
questions.explanation: David called out to Abner, questioning him respectfully for not protecting the king, showing boldness and accountability without disrespect (1 Samuel 26:14-16).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to take a shortcut that compromises honesty at work. How does 1 Samuel 26 provide a model for integrity?
options: David acted with integrity by not harming Saul even when he had the chance
David used deception to gain advantage over Saul
David ignored the situation and fled
David manipulated others for personal gain
questions.correctAnswer: David acted with integrity by not harming Saul even when he had the chance
questions.explanation: David had the opportunity to kill Saul but chose not to, demonstrating honesty and integrity even under pressure (1 Samuel 26:8-11, 23).

questions.question: How can 1 Samuel 26 teach us about contentment and gratitude in difficult circumstances?
options: David expressed gratitude for Saul’s recognition and spoke blessing over him
David complained about his hardships and envied Saul
David sought to complain to others about his situation
David refused to acknowledge any good in Saul
questions.correctAnswer: David expressed gratitude for Saul’s recognition and spoke blessing over him
questions.explanation: When Saul acknowledged his sin, David blessed him and wished him well, showing contentment and gratitude despite trials (1 Samuel 26:21, 25).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: David said, "The LORD render to every man his righteousness and his faithfulness: for the LORD delivered thee into my hand to day, but I would not stretch forth mine hand against the _________."
questions.correctAnswer: LORD'S anointed
questions.explanation: David specifically refused to harm Saul because he was the Lord’s anointed, as stated in 1 Samuel 26:23.

questions.question: According to 1 Samuel 26, what should a believer do when God’s timing for justice seems delayed?
options: Trust that the Lord will act in His time and refrain from taking matters into their own hands
Give up on justice and accept defeat
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that the Lord will act in His time and refrain from taking matters into their own hands
questions.explanation: David trusted that the Lord would smite Saul or that his day to die would come, showing patience and faith in God’s timing (1 Samuel 26:10, 23).

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 26 encourage believers to approach leadership within the community of faith?
options: Respect and honor God-ordained leaders even when they are flawed
questions.correctAnswer: Respect and honor God-ordained leaders even when they are flawed
questions.explanation: David respected Saul as the Lord’s anointed king and refused to harm him despite Saul’s pursuit, teaching respect for God-ordained authority (1 Samuel 26:9-11, 23).

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 26 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 26.

questions.question: What strategic location did the Ziphites inform Saul that David was hiding in?
questions.correctAnswer: The hill of Hachilah
questions.explanation: The Ziphites told Saul that David was hiding in the hill of Hachilah, which is before Jeshimon, as stated in 1 Samuel 26:1.

questions.question: How many chosen men did Saul take with him to seek David in the wilderness of Ziph?
questions.correctAnswer: Three thousand
questions.explanation: Saul arose and took three thousand chosen men of Israel to seek David, according to 1 Samuel 26:2.

questions.question: Who did David ask to accompany him in going down to Saul's camp?
questions.correctAnswer: Abishai
questions.explanation: David asked Ahimelech and Abishai who would go down with him to Saul’s camp, and Abishai volunteered, as recorded in 1 Samuel 26:6.

questions.question: What was Saul doing when David and Abishai came to his camp by night?
questions.correctAnswer: Sleeping within the trench
questions.explanation: Saul was sleeping within the trench, with his spear stuck in the ground by his bolster, as described in 1 Samuel 26:7.

questions.question: What reason did David give for not allowing Abishai to kill Saul?
options: Who can stretch forth his hand against the LORD'S anointed, and be guiltless?
David wanted to capture Saul alive
God had commanded to spare Saul
questions.correctAnswer: Who can stretch forth his hand against the LORD'S anointed, and be guiltless?
questions.explanation: David refused to kill Saul because he recognized him as the LORD’s anointed and said no one could harm him without guilt, found in 1 Samuel 26:9.

questions.question: What items did David take from Saul’s camp without waking anyone?
options: The spear and the cruse of water
questions.correctAnswer: The spear and the cruse of water
questions.explanation: David took the spear and the cruse of water from Saul’s bolster without waking anyone, as stated in 1 Samuel 26:11-12.

questions.question: From where did David call out to Abner and the people after taking Saul’s spear?
options: From the top of a hill afar off
questions.correctAnswer: From the top of a hill afar off
questions.explanation: David went over to the other side and stood on the top of a hill afar off to call out to Abner and the people, as per 1 Samuel 26:13.

questions.question: What accusation did David make against Abner regarding Saul’s safety?
options: You have not kept your lord the king
You have allied with David's enemies
You have fled from the battlefield
questions.correctAnswer: You have not kept your lord the king
questions.explanation: David accused Abner of failing to protect Saul, saying, 'Wherefore then hast thou not kept thy lord the king?' in 1 Samuel 26:15.

questions.question: What did David say was worth much in his eyes, referencing Saul’s life?
questions.correctAnswer: Saul’s life
questions.explanation: David said, 'as thy life was much set by this day in mine eyes,' meaning Saul’s life was precious to him, in 1 Samuel 26:24.

questions.question: How did Saul respond after David’s rebuke and demonstration of mercy?
options: He admitted he had sinned and vowed no more harm
questions.correctAnswer: He admitted he had sinned and vowed no more harm
questions.explanation: Saul said, 'I have sinned... I will no more do thee harm,' acknowledging his error in 1 Samuel 26:21.

questions.question: How does the episode of sparing Saul in 1 Samuel 26 foreshadow New Testament teachings about mercy and anointing?
options: It prefigures Christ's teaching on loving enemies and respecting God’s chosen
It anticipates the destruction of enemies without mercy
It reflects the establishment of a new temple
It predicts the exile of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures Christ's teaching on loving enemies and respecting God’s chosen
questions.explanation: David’s refusal to harm the LORD’s anointed foreshadows Jesus’ teachings in the New Testament about loving enemies and respecting God's anointed, such as in Matthew 5:44.

questions.question: The Hebrew word for 'anointed' used in 1 Samuel 26:9 is "mashiach" (מָשִׁיחַ). What is the theological significance of this term in the context of the passage?
options: It signifies one chosen and consecrated by God, highlighting Saul’s divine appointment despite his faults
It means a warrior leader appointed by popular vote
It refers to a king who must be overthrown
It denotes a priest only, not a king
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies one chosen and consecrated by God, highlighting Saul’s divine appointment despite his faults
questions.explanation: The term 'mashiach' denotes someone consecrated by God, emphasizing Saul’s divine appointment as king, making it sinful to harm him, as seen in 1 Samuel 26:9.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used when David retrieves Saul’s spear and cruse of water and then calls out to the camp?
questions.correctAnswer: Dramatic irony
questions.explanation: The narrative uses dramatic irony as the reader knows David has the spear and water, demonstrating his mercy, while Saul and his men remain unaware, shown in 1 Samuel 26:11-13.

questions.question: True or False: After this event, Saul immediately makes David his commander in Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Though Saul blesses David and promises no harm (1 Samuel 26:25), he does not appoint David as his commander or successor at this time.

questions.question: Which character in the passage is noted as the captain of Saul's host?
questions.correctAnswer: Abner
questions.explanation: Abner son of Ner is identified as the captain of Saul's host in 1 Samuel 26:5.

questions.question: What phrase does David use to describe Saul's pursuit of him, illustrating the futility of Saul's efforts?
options: The king of Israel is come out to seek a flea
The lion hunts the gazelle in vain
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Israel is come out to seek a flea
questions.explanation: David compares Saul’s pursuit to hunting a flea, emphasizing its futility, as recorded in 1 Samuel 26:20.

questions.question: What cultural or historical significance does Saul’s spear hold in this narrative?
options: It symbolizes the king’s authority and life, which David spares
It is a common weapon with no special meaning
It is a religious artifact used in sacrifices
It represents the covenant between Saul and David
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the king’s authority and life, which David spares
questions.explanation: The spear represents Saul’s royal authority and life; David’s act of taking but not harming with it shows respect to the anointed king, as seen in 1 Samuel 26:11-16.

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 26 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 26 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What reason does David give for not harming Saul despite having the opportunity?
options: Because Saul is the LORD's anointed and to harm him would be guiltless
Because he fears Saul's army will retaliate
Because he wants to capture Saul alive
Because he does not want to shed blood
questions.correctAnswer: Because Saul is the LORD's anointed and to harm him would be guiltless
questions.explanation: David explicitly states in 1 Samuel 26:9 that he will not harm Saul because Saul is the LORD's anointed, and stretching out a hand against the LORD's anointed would bring guilt. This reflects the biblical principle of respecting God's appointed authority as seen in Exodus 22:28, Psalm 105:15, and Romans 13:1-2.

questions.question: Who accompanies David when he secretly approaches Saul's camp at night?
questions.correctAnswer: Abishai
questions.explanation: David asks who will go down with him, and Abishai responds affirmatively as seen in 1 Samuel 26:6-7. This highlights loyal companionship. Similar loyal followers appear in the lives of biblical leaders such as Jonathan with David (1 Samuel 18:1-3).

questions.question: What items does David take from Saul's camp, demonstrating restraint?
options: Saul's spear and a cruse of water
questions.correctAnswer: Saul's spear and a cruse of water
questions.explanation: David takes the spear and the cruse of water from Saul's bolster as a sign he did not intend harm (1 Samuel 26:11-12). This act symbolizes mercy and respect for divine authority, akin to the mercy shown by Joseph towards his brothers (Genesis 45:5-8).

questions.question: How does God intervene to protect Saul during David’s night visit to the camp?
options: By causing a deep sleep to fall upon Saul and his men
By sending a strong wind to scatter the army
By causing a storm to frighten the soldiers
questions.correctAnswer: By causing a deep sleep to fall upon Saul and his men
questions.explanation: The LORD causes a deep sleep to fall upon Saul and all his people so none awake during David’s visit (1 Samuel 26:12). This divine protection is consistent with God's sovereignty and protection as seen in Exodus 14:21-22 and Psalm 3:5.

questions.question: What accusation does David make against Abner regarding Saul's safety?
options: That Abner failed to protect the LORD's anointed king
That Abner planned to betray Saul
That Abner was secretly helping David
That Abner was absent from the camp
questions.correctAnswer: That Abner failed to protect the LORD's anointed king
questions.explanation: David rebukes Abner for not guarding Saul, saying it is not good and they are worthy to die for not keeping their master, the LORD's anointed (1 Samuel 26:15-16). This emphasizes the sacred duty to protect God's appointed leaders, reflecting the biblical principle of stewardship (Romans 13:4).

questions.question: What theological principle is taught by David’s refusal to kill Saul despite opportunity?
options: Respect for God's sovereign appointment of leaders
The necessity of vengeance against enemies
The futility of mercy in leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Respect for God's sovereign appointment of leaders
questions.explanation: David’s restraint shows reverence for God’s sovereign choice of Saul as king (1 Samuel 26:9). This aligns with biblical teaching about submitting to God-ordained authority (Hebrews 13:17, Romans 13:1-2), affirming God’s ultimate sovereignty.

questions.question: How does Saul respond upon realizing David spared his life?
options: He acknowledges his sin and promises not to harm David again
He orders a renewed pursuit of David
He flees the camp in fear
questions.correctAnswer: He acknowledges his sin and promises not to harm David again
questions.explanation: Saul admits he has sinned and asks David to return, promising no more harm (1 Samuel 26:21). This moment shows Saul’s recognition of David’s righteousness and God’s justice, mirroring repentance themes seen in other biblical figures (Psalm 51:4).

questions.question: What does David ask for in his prayer regarding his life and the king’s spear?
options: That the LORD rewards righteousness and faithfulness and delivers him from tribulation
That he may overthrow Saul and seize the throne
That he be granted immediate vengeance on Saul
That the people reject Saul as king
questions.correctAnswer: That the LORD rewards righteousness and faithfulness and delivers him from tribulation
questions.explanation: David prays that the LORD will render to everyone their righteousness and faithfulness and deliver him from all troubles (1 Samuel 26:23-24). This reflects trust in God's justice and protection, consistent with Psalms 37:6 and 1 Peter 2:23.

questions.question: What is the significance of the hill of Hachilah in this chapter?
options: It is where Saul pitched and David observed him
It is David's stronghold where he hid
It is the location of a great battle between Saul and David
It is where the people of Israel gathered to crown David
questions.correctAnswer: It is where Saul pitched and David observed him
questions.explanation: Saul pitched in the hill of Hachilah before Jeshimon, and David saw where Saul lay (1 Samuel 26:1,3,5). This setting is crucial for the narrative of mercy, illustrating God’s providential protection over both king and future king, reminiscent of God’s guidance in wilderness journeys (Exodus 19:2).

questions.question: How does David describe Saul’s pursuit of him in his plea to the king?
options: As one hunting a flea or a partridge in the mountains
As a lion chasing a lamb
As a bear seeking its prey
As a shepherd protecting his flock
questions.correctAnswer: As one hunting a flea or a partridge in the mountains
questions.explanation: David likens Saul’s pursuit to hunting a flea or a partridge (1 Samuel 26:20), illustrating the futility and triviality of Saul’s efforts against him. This metaphor reflects the biblical theme of God’s protection over the righteous (Psalm 91:1-4, Isaiah 40:11).

questions.question: What messianic theme can be drawn from David’s respect for Saul as the LORD’s anointed?
options: God’s anointed king as a type of Christ, showing mercy and respect for God’s plan
The rejection of kingship as a divine institution
The necessity of violent overthrow to establish God's kingdom
The futility of earthly authority compared to spiritual power
questions.correctAnswer: God’s anointed king as a type of Christ, showing mercy and respect for God’s plan
questions.explanation: David’s deference to Saul, the LORD’s anointed, prefigures Christ’s role as the ultimate Anointed One (Messiah), whose authority is to be respected and whose kingdom is established through mercy, not violence (Psalm 2:2, Acts 10:38, Hebrews 1:9).

questions.question: What does Saul’s recognition of David’s voice reveal about their relationship?
questions.correctAnswer: A father-son-like bond despite conflict
questions.explanation: Saul calls David “my son” upon hearing his voice (1 Samuel 26:17), reflecting a complex relationship of affection and authority reminiscent of other biblical father-son dynamics (Genesis 27:27-28, 2 Samuel 18:33).

questions.question: How does this chapter illustrate the attribute of God concerning justice and mercy?
options: By showing God’s protection over both Saul and David and David’s merciful restraint
By emphasizing human vengeance over divine justice
By showing God’s favoritism to David only
By promoting the idea of might makes right
questions.correctAnswer: By showing God’s protection over both Saul and David and David’s merciful restraint
questions.explanation: God’s justice and mercy are evident as He protects Saul while enabling David to show mercy, highlighting divine sovereignty and grace (1 Samuel 26:12, 9-11). This aligns with Psalms 103:8-12 and Micah 6:8.

questions.question: What does David’s act of retrieving Saul’s spear symbolize in the larger biblical narrative?
options: His respect for God’s anointed and rejection of usurpation
His claim to the throne by force
His intention to kill Saul later
His alliance with Saul against other enemies
questions.correctAnswer: His respect for God’s anointed and rejection of usurpation
questions.explanation: Taking the spear but not killing Saul symbolizes David’s respect for God’s appointed king and his refusal to seize power unlawfully (1 Samuel 26:11-12). This foreshadows Christ’s kingship established through obedience, not rebellion (Philippians 2:8-9).

questions.question: What role does the Holy Spirit implicitly play in the events of this chapter?
options: Causing the deep sleep and guiding David’s restraint
questions.correctAnswer: Causing the deep sleep and guiding David’s restraint
questions.explanation: The chapter notes a deep sleep from the LORD (1 Samuel 26:12), reflecting the Spirit’s sovereign control over events. The Spirit’s guidance is also implied in David’s wisdom and mercy, consistent with the Spirit’s role in leading and restraining (Psalm 143:10, John 14:26).

questions.question: How does the interaction between Saul and David in this chapter contribute to understanding God’s plan for salvation history?
options: It shows God’s providential protection over the future king despite present opposition
It emphasizes the immediate establishment of David’s kingdom
It portrays Saul as completely rejected by God
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God’s providential protection over the future king despite present opposition
questions.explanation: The narrative demonstrates God’s sovereign plan to preserve David, the future messianic king, illustrating that human opposition cannot thwart God’s purposes (1 Samuel 26:12-25). This is consistent with the overarching biblical theme of God’s redemptive providence (Genesis 50:20, Romans 8:28).
